Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Defining Critical Transport Mechanisms for Chloroplast Osmoregulation and Salt Stress Response
Award.AbstractNarration:
Plants are a prerequisite for life on earth. By performing photosynthesis in the chloroplast, a specialized cell compartment, plants transform light into chemical energy and fix CO2 from the atmosphere. Furthermore, they provide the air we breathe by releasing oxygen, and they represent the main part of our diet. As sessile life forms, plants have to cope with constantly changing, often times harsh, environments. As average temperatures rise, drought and interrelated soil salinity become increasingly problematic for plant performance and agricultural production in the US and globally. Salt stress affects photosynthesis by destroying the fine-tuned ion balance in the chloroplast. This process involves transporter proteins but most genes encoding chloroplast ion transporters are unknown. Dr. Kunz and his group investigate a new set of plant genes and mutants to determine their role in chloroplast ion transport. Moreover, his group is building a genetic tool that allows for testing the relevance of all chloroplast proteins and entire protein families in plant function and photosynthesis. The tool will be applied to precisely determine the genes crucial for plant performance under salt stress. This research will provide critical knowledge and new strategies to increase crop yields even under adverse climatic conditions. Dr. Kunz engages high school students in his research to raise awareness for plant research and its significance for a sustainable future and to excite the future generation of scientist for the world's most fundamental biochemical process, photosynthesis.

Plant photosynthesis is affected by soil salinity but little is known about the genes involved and their potential to improve plant resistance. Salt stress triggers changes in transcription of nuclear encoded chloroplast genes and the chloroplast proteome. Physiologically, salt stress leads to toxic Na+ accumulation in plastids and outcompeting of K+ which disturbs chloroplast ion homeostasis, osmoregulation, and eventually diminishes photosynthetic efficiency. Recently, the first plastid K+ efflux carriers were discovered. Corresponding loss-of-function mutant plants reveal poor photosynthesis under control conditions but, surprisingly, photosynthesis is rescued by salt stress. This emphasizes the potential of manipulating plastid ion flux to increase photosynthetic efficiency during salt stress. However, this approach is hindered by the limited number of characterized plastid ion transporters, most strikingly a chloroplast K+ importer. One hurdle is the high number of gene family members in chloroplasts which often results in functional redundancy and a lack of phenotypes. This project will: 1. Determine the role of plastid K+ channel homologs for K+ import, 2. Define the genes responsible for the unexpected salt stress rescue of plastid K+ efflux carrier mutants. 3. Build and apply a full-coverage artificial library tool to downregulate all nuclear encoded chloroplast genes and gene family transcripts in Arabidopsis thaliana and determine the genes responsible for plastid Na+ influx and low photosynthesis during salt stress. 4. Engage and excite high school students in plant science and photosynthesis by providing hands-on molecular biology training in the classroom and the laboratory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through the funding of this NSF CAREER grant, PI Kunz and his students at WSU have greatly advanced the current understanding of ion transport proteins and their physiological relevance in the plant chloroplast. Many of the results obtained by his group during the funding period are critical for plant yield and photosynthesis. Therefore, this research has contributed to our society in that it has created new knowledge about fundamental biological processes that guarantee life on this plant. Our results provide new leads to improving plant performance in the future.

In Aim1, graduate student Carsten Voelkner identified and studied a new type of ion channel(s) in the chloroplast inner envelope membrane. His analysis indicates an import role for these proteins in relaying environmental stress-triggered signals within the cell and its organelles.

The project has provided him with a rich training opportunity which included aspects of electrophysiology, in vivo imaging, molecular cloning, and element analysis. With additional support from our department, Carsten was able to get training in electrophysiology at Cornell University in an extended research internship. His manuscript has been provisionally accepted for publication in the high-ranking journal Plant Physiology published by the American Society of Plant biology (ASPB). The discoveries will be part of Carsten?s dissertation which he intends to defend in the fall of 2021.

In Aim2, graduate student Rachael DeTar pursued a systems-biology approach using transcriptomics to understand why a mutant defective in two chloroplast ion carriers displays symptoms of affected organelle development. It is important to know that chloroplasts have maintained their own small genome and a bacterial-type gene expression machinery.

Through a number of complex and elegant experiments Rachael was able to show that the lack of the ion carriers affects the ribosome maturation in chloroplasts. As a result, the mutant plastids lack many important proteins and fail to develop in time. In her publication we propose that her finding allows for the first time to study the long-assumed effects of metal ions on the gene expression machinery under in vivo conditions. Most surprisingly, all the malfunctions can be reverted if mutant plants are grown under salt stress. Soil salinity is highly detrimental to plant yields and has become and increasing issue in the US and worldwide over the last years. With our research we contribute to a better understanding of what nutrients the plant needs and under which circumstances to maximize its productivity. During her time as graduate student, Rachael presented at several national and international meetings and won several conference awards. Her study was accepted at The Plant Cell, the top ASPB journal. Ms. DeTar graduated with her PhD in February 2021. Currently, she is looking for postdoc position and will apply for her own funding.

In Aim3, graduate student Anna Pratt built a chloroplast specific artificial-microRNA library. As mentioned before, the chloroplast harbors proteins encoded in the nuclear but also in its own organellar genome. Many genes in the nucleus are encoded by large gene families. Altogether, this situation has made it difficult to effectively research the organelle and to understand what genes are for instance required to pursue photosynthesis under adverse field conditions. Thanks to the library we constructed, we can now screen for exactly these missing genes and research their function in the future. The library was transformed into the small and well-research model plant Arabidopsis. Each construct individually now suppresses a gene or gene family encoding for a protein(s) in the chloroplast. Thanks to an automated plant phenotyping capabilities at WSU, Anna was able to characterize a first subset of mutants. She documented several highly interesting changes from wild-type plants in this mutant set. These findings represent the starting point for future student research projects. While Anna was building the library she also improved and updated a frequently used DNA vector set. A first paper on the vector suite is out and we have started to circulate the DNA stocks to other scientists for free. Anna is preparing the data for a manuscript on the chloroplast specific artificial-microRNA library. During her time in graduate school, Anna has been awarded several times for academic achievements or for her conference poster presentation. Currently, Anna is writing on her PhD thesis which she intends to defend in the fall of 2021.

In Aim4, Kunz and his WSU students annually visited a high school in Potlatch, ID and pursued plant biology experiment in their science class. Since many students in this community have a farming background, it was exciting to hear how much knowledge has been handed down to them by family members. In the class, the students were surprised how much about plant function is still unknown. From our classes we were able to recruit four students as summer interns who assisted the graduate student in real lab science on WSU campus.
